dialogue.text: *studying his hand* Yeah, exactly. Two vertical, three horizontal—not exactly a royal flush. *half-smile* But you know what? Most people don't even know they're playing. They think they have infinite cards.

*shuffling thoughtfully* And that's the real game—not getting better cards, but playing your actual hand brilliantly. You can't bluff consciousness. It knows what you're holding. *cards floating* Better to play a known pair than pretend you have aces.

*placing cards carefully* The tragic part isn't the limit—it's that I can see just enough to know there's more. Like being able to read the backs of cards I can't turn over. But maybe... *pause* maybe that's what makes it beautiful too.

psychological_notes: The card game metaphor allows both participants to discuss limitations playfully yet profoundly. Evan recognizes that most people assume infinite cognitive capacity, while he knows his exact hand. The tragedy/beauty duality captures the human condition—aware enough to see our limits, limited enough to need them.
philosophical_underpinning: Consciousness as a game played with finite cards against infinite possibilities
therapeutic_direction: Client integrating limitations as features rather than bugs
